title: The Outernet
intro: Remember to subscribe to the podcast version !
this_week_question: What proportion of the world’s population still has no internet access? Is it…
a) a quarter? b) half? c) two thirds?

vocab.desc: an electronic device which you can store and read books from the internet
a long way from towns and cities
a person who makes money by starting their own business that typically involves some financial risk
send out electronic signals or programmes
the length of time it takes to complete something
the right to use other people's material or work without paying any fees
tall metal towers that send and receive signals

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil...

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: ...and I'm Catherine. Hello.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello, Catherine! Now, how was your holiday?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: My holiday was lovely, Neil. I was staying on a beautiful island. It was very remote and there was actually no internet access. So, I did feel quite cut off actually.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And cut off means isolated. How did you survive, Catherine?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Well, it wasn’t easy. But I had my e-reader - that's an electronic device which lets you store and read lots of books from the internet. And I read a lot of Harry Potter...

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Harry Potter? I know you like wizards, Catherine, but shouldn't you have downloaded some classic literature? How about Shakespeare’s The Tempest? That's got a wizard in it too.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Well, yes indeed. But Shakespeare on the beach isn't quite right for me, Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right. Well, today we're talking about how the poorer and more remote - or distant - parts of the world can get access to learning.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: That's right. But before we start, Neil, I believe you have a quiz question for us.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, I do. I would like to know what the proportion of the world's population that still has no internet access is. Is it...

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: I'm going to go for c) two thirds.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out if you're right or wrong later on in the programme. So Catherine, how can these people get connected to the internet and start surfing?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: By using the Outernet.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The Outer what?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: The Outernet. That's the idea of entrepreneur Syed Karim and its goal is to give people in unconnected communities access to information without having to use expensive mobile phones or two-way satellite networks.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I see. And an entrepreneur , by the way, is a person who makes money by starting their own business that typically involves some financial risk.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Yes, I've always fancied myself as a bit of an entrepreneur.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, you'll need money and ideas, Catherine. Have you got either of those?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: I've got ideas.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right. OK. I get it.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: So, can you tell us how the Outernet works, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, I can. The Outernet uses existing communications satellites to store and broadcast data - broadcast means to send out signals or programmes. Special equipment on the ground picks up - or receives - the data, and this can be copied to phones and computers.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: But the Outernet broadcasts data offline - which means it's not connected to the Internet. There's no communication with the internet for user - so, no emails, no chat forums. And that can be a big drawback - or disadvantage.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. The Outernet doesn't provide two-way communication. But let's hear Syed Karim discussing why one-way access has some advantages. And see if you can spot another word meaning 'two-way'.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Syed Karim, business entrepreneur Anything that is related to bi-directional communications, the internet, to be able to provide that to the entire world, those are billion dollar projects, multi-billion dollar projects with huge time horizons and enormous complexity. And, you know, our solution that we are offering is instantaneous, I mean, it exists right now.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Did you get it? Another way of saying two-way is bi-directional . So what are the advantages of one-way communication, Catherine?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: It's significantly cheaper. Bi-directional communications are multi-billion dollar projects. But the Outernet allows poorer communities to benefit from access to information.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, it does. And the other big problem is the time it would take to establish two-way access. Syed says these projects have huge time horizons - and this means the length of time it takes to complete a project - they're huge, so very big.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: But the Outernet is already providing access to some of the world's most valuable knowledge.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's right. The project aims to create a library of information taken from websites including Wikipedia and Project Gutenberg, which is a collection of copyright-free e-books. Copyright-free means the right to use material without paying any fees.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: That sounds good. But let's go back to the internet and hear from a BBC reporter talking about another project which aims to get people connected.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: BBC reporter Google for example is working on Project Loon, a network of high-altitude helium balloons, which will boost Internet connections across much wider areas beyond coverage from conventional masts.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It's called Project Loon - meaning crazy - because Google thought it was such a crazy idea, and loon sounds like balloon!

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Yeah. The idea is that users will connect to the balloon network - or group of interconnected balloons - using an antenna attached to their building. The signal travels through the balloon network from balloon to balloon, and then to a station on the ground that's connected to the Internet.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The balloons will boost - or increase - the number of people who will be able to access the Internet.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Yes, it will. And that's because there will be lots of them - compared to the number of masts - or tall metal towers that send and receive signals - that are currently used.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, let's have the answer to the quiz question I asked: What proportion of the world's population still has no internet access? Is it ... a) a quarter? b) half? or c) two thirds?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: And I said c) two thirds.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And you were right! The answer is two thirds. Well done, Catherine.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now just time to listen to today's words once again. Catherine.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: OK. We heard:

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. I hope you enjoyed connecting with us today! Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
